1423113381|1.0|I know Rick Riordan can do better than this since he already has with the Percy Jackson series. I won't compare the two, but I will say that excellent children's books do exist, and this is not even close. Ancient Greek mythology and ancient Egyptian culture are probably the two most popular subjects that exist. Most people find them fascinating. I was very excited when I heard about this book and have been waiting to read it for some time. When I found out more about it I was even more excited. A coming of age story with magical powers thrown in on top of the ancient Egyptian theme-awesome. So what went wrong?<br /><br />First, no character development. There are two narrators, a brother and sister, and they don't really have their own personalities. They go through the motions, complete tasks, and have conversations, but there isn't much there personality wise. Sure, one of them dresses in combat boots, and the other one is a bit bookish, but that's all we get. In other books the characters have clear personalities. Examples: Fablehaven, Harry Potter, or even the Percy Jackson series. Each character is distinguishable and unique. That is not the case here, and the book suffers from it. I really think authors need to know that a long drawn out action sequence is just not good enough.<br /><br />Which brings me to the second problem with this book, the plot. There is a bad guy that wants to destroy the world and the main characters have to stop him. Not too deep, but not much different from the general plot in the other books I mentioned. What makes it a problem in this book? The way plot is developed. The characters go where they are told to start the novel. Then, they run into someone that tells them to go see someone else. They go see that person, who then leads them to another person. Get the idea? In the middle of this there will be some danger in the form of a monster or a dangerous location. A book that consists almost entirely of go here do this, go there do that, fight something, go retrieve something, then go talk to this person, is just not good enough. I've played those video games before, they are boring.<br /><br />My third issue is the bad guys. Why is it that children's books never have deep, intelligent, powerful, bad guys? They are always cardboard muahaha style baddies, and The Red Pyramid is no exception. When the bad guy decides to have a long drawn out conversation in the middle of a fight I cringe. The bad guys are just too cheesy in this book, and it's sad. I guess if the main characters have no depth, then their enemies can't be expected to have any either. The super powerful Egyptian entities are no better. They are all eccentric, and some come off as stupid. I don't appreciate powerful beings acting like five year olds. I don't understand why the author chose to portray them that way, it is certainly not funny to me. I guess having Bast constantly reference Friskies is supposed to be funny, but I personally didn't like it.<br /><br />The last issue that I will mention is progression. I like my characters to mature and progress, but again, if they have no personalities, there isn't much to improve upon. The plot was agonizingly slow as well. I was getting tired of the book by the third of fourth person the characters met, and there was at least twenty more to go at that point. If the interactions with these new characters had any effect on the outcome of the book I may have been more interested. Instead, they simply pointed the characters in the direction of the next task.<br /><br />I can't think of a single thing I enjoyed about this book except maybe the beginning before the danger came into play. I really am sick of books where the characters go through the motions and complete task after task. I've read other books where the entire thing feels like one big chase scene, and this is no different. I won't be continuing with this series, and it's a shame because the author could have done so well with the ancient Egpytian theme. Instead, he chose to trivialize everything in a weak attempt at humor that just didn't work for me.e chose to trivialize everything in a weak attempt at humor that just didn't work for me.

0307454541|1.0|I really don't get it.  Maybe I'm just an old square who's fussy about language and plot, but I am astonished that this book is being so widely praised.  I can imagine it making a good movie along the lines of \\"Silence of the Lambs,\\" but as a piece of writing and plotting it is strictly amateur hour.  There are so many simple mistakes that a high-school English teacher would put a red check next to: words used twice within a couple of sentences; characters saying the same thing twice, even three times as if saying them for the first time; details \\"revealed\\" when the same detail was revealed two chapters before.  The list goes on.  And the plot?  Yes, there's a plot, one that could have been given full treatment in a book half or less the length of \\"Girl with the Dragon Tattoo.\\"  As I read the endless exposition, I found myself longing for something to happen in the here and now, for some movement forward -- and longing in vain for chapter after chapter.  I was forced to endure characters who not only had nothing to do with the story but added nothing to the interest factor, and a climax rendered completely unsatisfying because the villain turns out to be someone in whom I have been led to have almost zero interest.  Anyway, I know I'm in the minority and wasting my time with this review, but I had to write something in protest to the notion that this lame, repetitive writing and universe of uninteresting characters (not including the core few around whom a pared-down version could have enjoyably revolved) has become the sort of stuff of which a \\"publishing phenomenon\\" is made today.

B002ZG99A4|5.0|\\"The Expendables\\" is great! This is how the story goes: Barney Ross is a man with nothing to lose. Fearless and void of emotion, he is the leader, the sage and the strategist of this tight-knit band of men who live on the fringe. His only attachment is to his pickup truck, his seaplane and his team of loyal modern-day warriors. His is a true cynic who describes what he does as 'removing those hard to get at stains'. The team behind him is made up of Lee Christmas, former SAS and a savant with anything that has a blade; Ying Yang, a master at close-quarter combat; Hale Caesar, who has known Barney for ten years and is a long-barrel weapons specialist; Toll Road, a skilled demolitions expert and considered the intellect of the group; and Gunner Jensen, a combat veteran and an expert in precision sniping who struggles with his own demons. When the mysterious Church offers Barney a job no one else would take, Barney and his team embark on what appears to be a routine mission: overthrow General Gaza, the murderous dictator of the small island country of Vilena and end the years of death and destruction inflicted on its people. On a reconnaissance mission to Vilena, Barney and Christmas meet their contact Sandra, a local freedom-fighter with a dark secret. They also come to learn who their true enemy is: rogue ex-CIA operative James Munroe and his henchman Paine. When things go terribly wrong, Barney and Christmas are forced to leave Sandra behind, essentially giving her a death sentence. Haunted by this failure, Barney convinces the team to return to Vilena to rescue the hostage and finish the job he started. And to perhaps save a soul: his own. B000002AZ8|5.0|It was a cold week, Thanksgiving, 1994. No file sharing, no downloading, no Britney Spears, no American Idol. The Spice Girls were not even  out yet.  Kurt Cobain had died seven months earlier. But Seattle music still ruled the world. If you are not old enough to remember the 1980s, having to endure hair bands and Micheal Jackson and digital drumming, a absence of pure rock and roll on the charts, it is hard to conceive how cool grunge felt. It was not the 1960s, but here were guys who acted like you, dressed like you, guys you could hang out with, putting out rock and roll records. You really thought in the 1980s this would never happen again--but here it was. As immediate as that turkey defrosting on the counter, that vital fall '94 air.<br /><br />Even if you owned no flannel, even if you had a great job, a college degree, hung out in sophisticated circles, if you had any love for rock as an art form, grunge brought music as you knew it back into the world. It felt SO good. Like not breathing--then getting air back.<br /><br />Not only that. Pearl Jam had released [[ASIN:B0000028UK Vs.]] only a year before. By the 1990s, a band could wait five years before making an album. But out of no place, Pearl Jam released a one off surprise, a  new album that was out just in time for the Thanksgiving weekend. A holiday gift. What a good old fashioned, rock and roll thing to do.<br /><br />Vitalogy, in fact, has a one off feel, one of those albums a band cuts quick, maybe just off the road, when they have ten or twelve songs burning a hole in their pockets and knock them off in a white hot studio week. After the big production of [[ASIN:B0000027RL Ten]] and the anticipation of Vs., Vitalogy felt fresh as a daisy.<br /><br />\\"Spin The Black Circle\\" was the single, and, if you have not figured, is about playing records; Vitalogy came out on vinyl--rare by '94. Listen to this melodic metal, how fast and easy Pearl Jam play it. They sound as though they found the right chords, the right words, the right stars in place on the right night. \\"Spin The Black Circle,\\" is ripped off faster than you can say \\"rock and roll is back.\\"<br /><br />\\"Tremor Christ\\" has a slow burn. Melodic, careful, but still fresh, live sounding. These two tracks are typical of Vitalogy, which is packed with what feel like unplanned experiments, jams, a band after a hot gig who go into a club after hours and just rip the paint off the walls.  \\"Pry To,\\" is almost as funky and live as those old Al Kooper/Mike Bloomfield jams, and \\"Stupidmop\\" is improvise sound collage.<br /><br />Do you believe this was SIXTEEN years ago. Babies I saw when I went to the mall to get this--that's right, we had to leave the house, kiddies,-are making my Starbucks now. We're in a digital mess, too big for anyone to rule like Pearl Jam did JUST before the world got completely connected for good.<br /><br />I don't know if there will ever be a rock album like this, but it is nice to think back, and remember those two great events,<br /><br />Vitalogy, and Thanksgiving.<br /><br />1994e on the right night. \\"Spin The Black Circle,\\" is ripped off faster than you can say \\"rock and roll is back.\\"  \\"Tremor Christ\\" has a slow burn. Melodic, careful, but still fresh, live sounding. These two tracks are typical of Vitalogy, which is packed with what feel like unplanned experiments, jams, a band after a hot gig who go into a club after hours and just rip the paint off the walls.  \\"Pry To,\\" is almost as funky and live as those old Al Kooper/Mike Bloomfield jams, and \\"Stupidmop\\" is improvise sound collage.  Do you believe this was SIXTEEN years ago. Babies I saw when I went to the mall to get this--that's right, we had to leave the house, kiddies,-are making my Starbucks now. We're in a digital mess, too big for anyone to rule like Pearl Jam did JUST before the world got completely connected for good.  I don't know if there will ever be a rock album like this, but it is nice to think back, and remember those two great events,  Vitalogy, and Thanksgiving.  1994
0525951652|5.0|Ken Follett's new novel, \\"Fall of Giants\\", is a big boy. It's so big that it could be used as a door stop for a steel door. But I have a feeling that most people reading this review already know it's a big book and don't expect anything less from Ken Follett.<br /><br />\\"Giants\\" is the first in a trilogy about the 20th century. At least I assume it is, because this book is about the run-up to the \\"Great War\\" (WW1) and the four years of war. Follett, as usual, has many characters from Europe and the United States. Most are fictional but some are real. He has the talent to draw these many fictional characters with a deft brush, nuanced-enough to be distinguishable from each other. That's no mean feat, actually; how many novels have you read whose characters just blend into each other and you're never sure about who's who? To help out, though, Follett puts a \\"character page\\" in the front of the book.<br /><br />I can't decide if the reader has to have fundamental knowledge of WW1 to appreciate this book. Follett is a pretty good amateur historian and he's written an excellent \\"historical novel\\". So, I guess it would appeal to, and help teach, readers of any kind. I thought the same thing about his novels about medieval England.<br /><br />Follett follows the fortunes and fates of roughly 10 main characters. All intersect to a certain extent - thwarted lovers, Welsh miners-from-Russia, and diplomats-trying-to-prevent-war - in Follett's pages. I'm looking forward to Follett's next two books in the trilogy to learn what happens to these people as the 20th century unfolds. He's a good writer, as most anyone reading this book would probably agree.
B003I55BIA|5.0|I generally prefer my YA novels to feature urban fantasy settings but after reading the great reviews of this book, I decided to give it a try. Wow! I simply could not put the book down and ended up pulling an all-nighter in order to finish it. And for a mom who values sleep more than just about anything else, that's saying a lot.<br /><br />It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out the basic plot points of this story: bad boy meets good girl, falls in love, chaos ensues, and eventually a happy ending materializes. But the fantastic, multifaceted characters, emotional depth, realistic trials and tribulations keep the reader engaged and invested in the story. The writing is top-notch and Elkeles' ability to effortlessly portray characters from various backgrounds and income brackets is impressive. I also liked her treatment of teen sex and drug use -- it exists but it's not glorified and the characters who engage in it are aware of the possible repercussions.<br /><br />But let's not kid ourselves. By far the biggest draw of this novel is the male lead. Alex is truly every girl (and woman's) idea of the perfect bad boy: sexy, smart, funny, impulsive, kind of bad-ass, with a heart of gold. He's not perfect, by any stretch, but his flaws only make him more endearing.<br /><br />So even if this genre isn't your cup of tea or you prefer your male leads to be tall, dark, and dead....give it a try. I think you will be pleasantly surprised. I know I was.

B002VZC9CY|5.0|I have listened to Natalie Merchant since she was lead vocal with 10,000 Maniacs.  I loved her then and loved when she went solo.  \\"Leave Your Sleep\\" takes her music to the next higher level of artistry.<br /><br />As others have said, these are not children's pieces of music per se, although children will enjoy some of the selections, such as the whimsical \\"Bleezer's Ice Cream\\" and \\"Griselda\\". This was a five-year labor of love for Merchant, I believe so that she could leave it as a lasting treasure for her own daughter.<br /><br />These songs are poems set to music by Merchant.  She meticulously researched each piece of poetry and each poet, wrote wonderful historical notes about each piece and then set them to the music she believed they should be set to.  The CD notes are bound in a gorgeous little book and the whole CD presentation is exceptionally high quality including the paper that was used and the photographs selected.  I buy MP3 downloads for almost all of my music now but in this case I actually bought the CD set (after listening to it from the library).  It is truly a collector's item.<br /><br />The songs/music are varied, some haunting such as \\"If No One Ever Marries Me\\" to toe tapping \\"The Janitor's Boy\\".  I loved every song on both CD's and I can't remember the last time I was able to say that.

B000UNYJXQ|5.0|I'm a medical insider, a physician, and I can tell you that Moore went very easy on providers in this film. He could have gone after overly competitive, anal, greedy providers (nurses, docs, physician assistants) as well, but he decided to focus on the administrative side of things. At least providers do the actual work of seeing patients, but let me assure you that there are many people, and not as many docs as you would think, pulling millions of dollars out of the medical insurance pot. So it is also in the pharmaceutical business. These are the \\"suits\\" or the business types who really don't provide much of anything, but have, smelling money as their guide, rooted their way to the money trough and into the control tower. Believe me, the last thing they care about is \\"quality health care.\\" They care about making lots of money. They leave the \\"quality\\" to overly-worked health care providers as they shove the lever from \\"fast\\" to \\"faster\\" with one hand while in the other hand they hold a computer print-out stating production times and profit. \\"If we could only get rid of a few providers and make the others work harder.....\\" or, if we could only reduce the time providers spend with people we could up the numbers of patients seen per day.\\"<br /><br />Moore got it right, but he didn't turn over the last rock.

Looking some of them up on Google Earth helped to put them in context. One word of warning: the story is violent in many parts and people who find graphic details of that type of thing objectionable or upsetting would probably not find this book easy to read.<br /><br />The writing was excellent and I was sorry to learn that Stieg Larsson died soon after signing a contract for this book and his two others. B00008972S|5.0|I've just watched \\"West Side Story,\\" first released in 1961. Shooting on this film began almost exactly fifty years ago (at the time of this writing) in NYC on 10 August 1960, so it seemed fitting to view it near that anniversary date. My nephew had expressed interest in seeing the picture, since he had learned one of the songs in music class. And it's been many, many years since I last viewed it, so I thought it a good choice for this weekend.<br /><br />I have to say, I had forgotten just how very good this film is. With a fantastic score and great orchestrations, wonderful choreography, and a story with real emotional pull; all the elements are in place. Now, the bits of the plot that deal with the finer aspects of gang warfare do seem rather quaintly old-fashioned, considering the level of violence that exists in the inner cities today. But then, I don't know that the film was meant to be particularly realistic even when it was shot; it was always a stylised version of reality, rather than a matter-of-fact slice of life.<br /><br />The performances are uniformly good, with Rita Moreno a stand-out. Much could be said about the casting of Natalie Wood, a white girl in a Hispanic role---today it would almost certainly be cast with an actress of the correct ethnicity. However, I think she does do a fine job in the part.<br /><br />Sadly enough, this film seems every bit as topical today---an entire half-century later--- as it did when it was shot. Currently the issues of immigration and racism are hot-button topics in American politics, and are surely going to figure heavily in the upcoming elections.<br /><br />I have the two-DVD \\"special edition\\" of the film, and that is definitely the version to get, until such a time as a Blu-ray is released. The special edition set gives you the widescreen print of the film with a 5.1 surround audio mix, a booklet containing the script and additional information, plus an additional disc containing bonus features.<br /><br />Most interesting of the bonus material is an hour-long documentary detailing the making of the film. The documentary contains a lot of footage shot behind-the-scenes, as well as some footage where you can hear Natalie Wood's own vocals for the musical numbers. Natalie actually recorded all of her own songs, and the film was shot to this playback. But in the end it was decided that her vocals weren't quite strong enough, and Marni Nixon was brought in to dub her singing voice. Marni really was the go-to-gal for musical dubbing for a ten-year period or so: from the mid fifties to the mid sixties she dubbed a number of very famous musicals (including \\"My Fair Lady\\" and \\"The King and I\\"). I have to say, Marni does a great job here; her voice is a good fit for Natalie's speaking voice. But what a difficult job that must have been! Not only did she have to deliver a good vocal performance, she had to exactly match the sync on film that was already shot.<br /><br />So, a definite recommendation from me. This is one of those films that is so much a part of pop culture, and the history of the American theatre, that I think everyone should give it a try at least once. As for how it plays to a modern 12-year-old, well... My nephew Joshua did find it rather long, but did stick it out to the end.<br /><br />Bit of trivia:  The opening of this film was notable at the time for the way it began with long aerial shots of the city, with the camera gradually moving closer and closer to street level as the sounds of city life slowly became audible, before finally focusing in on individual characters at ground level. The film was directed by Robert Wise, who later directed \\"The Sound of Music,\\" and he was very resistant to the idea of using the same technique for the opening of \\"Music;\\" fortunately he eventually changed his mind. It's interesting that, all these years later, it is actually the opening of \\"The Sound of Music\\" that is better remembered and more famous than that of \\"West SideStory.\\"

0307474712|2.0|[This review is of the Audible version, narrated by Anna Bentinck. Ms. Bentinck's reading of this work is wonderful. By very slight nuances of voice or pacing, she effectively inhabits the various characters, keeping even long scenes of dialog completely clear as to who was speaking and what they might have been feeling. The narrator's voice also was distinct from the characters', and this all seemed quite effortless and un-\\"acted\\". Kudos.]    This book is lovely in its writing, with many passages of narrative, and especially dialogue, to savor. The language envelops the reader deeply into the story without calling attention to itself, and it was because of the writing that I was pulled to continue with the story, waiting for a payoff that, unfortunately, never came (or rather, came too late to undo the ennui that had set in early and remained for the duration of this dreary book). The organization and structure of the book is, as many others have pointed out, interesting and unusual - checking in on Em and Dex on St. Swithin's Day each year following their initial night together.     However, the story itself is dismal, the characters depressing, the scenes often just excruciating and cringe-making (Dex's scene with his dying mother, e.g.), with the narrative arc sputtering along in stop-and-start fashion along a flat and uninteresting plane, year after year after year. Character development is almost nil. Emma does eventually grow and change, making a life for herself as a waitress, then a teacher, and finally a writer. But Dex simply continues his alcoholic womanizing, riding an endless wave of self-delusion and whining for years until he finally marries Emma, at which time he finally grows up. (Why? How? There was no foreshadowing of growing up for this character.) But only temporarily! As soon as Emma is gone, down goes Dex again, back into his bottle, back under his rock. This time it's because he's grieving. Well, ok.    Fundamental unanswered questions: whydoes Emma even like a poseur like Dex, much less love him, for years on end? Why is Dex, with all his advantages, such an alcoholic, womanizing, self-pitying, boring loser, and why should we care about him? Why does Dex love Emma, who is nice enough and eventually grows out of her own self-righteousness  to become sufficiently accomplished, but is generally dull and not very interesting?     Finally, the payoff limps in, a day late and a dollar short, in the genuinely lovely last scene of the book, which flashes back to continue the story of Em and Dex on their first day following their first night. (This is the first we hear of their having spent the following day together.) Nichols takes time with this scene; finally we see both in a much more sympathetic and endearing light and at long last, we find ourselves wishing them well. Finally we understand why they loved each other all these years. But please: it was their first day after their first night -- why not give it to us right up front, to underwrite the otherwise inexplicable emotion that bound these two together? Why this coy, counterintuitive, backwards structure? We see these characters for hundreds (seems like thousands) of pages mostly at their worst before we finally get to see them as they were when they initially fell in love. A dozen times I wanted to abandon the story on the grounds of boredom and irritation but was kept engaged by the beautiful writing. Why waste such great writing on such a dreary story?     At the end of the day, it's like one of those made-for-tv movies that are just engaging enough to keep you from changing the channel, but when it's over you smack yourself upside the head for having wasted your time and good will.

068817776X|4.0|A co-worker loaned this book to me, thinking I would like to read it. Notice that I didn't say \\"enjoy\\" reading it, because it most certainly isn't the type of book that one enjoys reading. But to say that I was left untouched by it would be a lie. The story of Edith Hahn Beer's life is unbelievable, intriguing, and startling all at the same time.    Edith's saga begins as a Jewish schoolgirl before World War ll, with a childhood in Vienna in an extended family. By 1938, the Nazi influence in Vienna had wrecked havoc on the Jewish people. Edith had been attending the University of Vienna and was one test away from graduating with her law degree, her goal was to be a judge. She was turned away from taking her final exam, told she was no longer welcomed because of her heritage, her bloodline. It wasn't long before Edith was sent to Osterburg to work as a slave laborer on a farm. The time spent here was extremely hard on Edith, yet she met people and learned things that would help her survive in the years yet to come. Upon her return to Vienna, nothing was as it was when she left, her family was gone and there were few friends to help. Yet with the help of a special Christian Aryan friend, Christina Margarethe Denner, Edith was able to secure her identity and leave Vienna as a German.     Thus began Edith's new life as \\"Grete\\", the woman who eventually met and married a Nazi Party Member, Werner Vetter, who became a Nazi officer, and was eventually taken prisoner and served time in Siberia. It was only by forcing herself to forget her family, her heritage, her schooling, and concentrate on being a naive, unschooled, shy \\"German\\" that \\"Grete\\" was able to survive and pass unnoticed amongst her neighbors. Edith had confessed to Werner her true identity but he did not betray her.     I have read other publications and watched shows about the Holocaust, all of which have left me shaken with disbelief, anger, tears - so many emotions. Edith Hahn Beer's saga gave me a new perspective to view the Holocaust from and to wonder if I would have the courage, the tenacity to do what Edith did if placed in a similar position. This is a book that should be read because while it is disturbing, it is also triumphant, and it dares us to remember what happened during those dark years.

I would watch this movie if you want food for thought and deep-set emotional drama, not if you want something happy and fulfilling.

We have the Indiana Jones of Symbology himself, Robert Langdon; the essential heroine, Katherine Solomon; the insane and fanatically driven bad guy; the mysterious, if at least not religious, organisation; The Freemasons; and a grizzly discovery, all brought together in the capitol of the U.S.A. Washington D.C.<br /><br />All sounding too familiar? It was. However! B000VLOKQI|4.0|Considering all that has been written about The Who by music critics, biographers and pop journalists, there is not much left to say about this forceful, inventive and influential English rock aggregate. Thanks to \\"Amazing Journey\\", however, there are still fresh things to see.<br />  The twin DVDs in this set produced by Nigel Sinclair, Bill Curbishley and Robert Rosenberg include \\"The Story of The Who\\" and \\"Six Quick Ones\\". These documentaries assemble live performances and recording sessions, archival newsreels, television and movie clips, interviews with the principals, their managers, producers, family, friends, and fellow rock musicians (Sting, The Edge, Eddie Vedder, Noel Gallgher, Steve Jones, and others) from 1964 through 2003.<br />  \\"The Story of The Who\\" tracks the band's career from the earliest days of their emergence from among scores of English performers scrambling for attention in the wake of the commercial tsunami known as the \\"British Invasion\\" of 1964, spearheaded by The Beatles' successful penetration of the American marketplace.<br />  The extraordinary thing about this footage is that there is so much of it. That is owed to The Who's first managers, Chris Stamp and Kit Lambert - entertainment industry promoters with no particular ear for pop music - who surveyed the lively London scene in the spring of '64 looking for a promising group to manage and to film in action for a movie. Their selection of The Who - then billing themselves as The High Numbers - for their project proved to be miraculous. Suppose they had picked Herman's Hermits or The Dave Clark Five? They could not have foreseen any more than the band themselves did that The Who would become rock immortals.<br />  The hits started coming immediately. \\"I Can't Explain\\", \\"The Kids Are Alright\\", \\"My Generation\\", \\"Magic Bus\\", \\"Happy Jack\\", and \\"I Can See For Miles\\" were chartbusters in Great Britain and the U.S.A. The documentary cameras continued to roll. The Who recorded an advertising jingle for Coca-Cola , which inspired their first concept album \\"The Who Sell Out\\".<br />  One could isolate The Who's four consecutive studio albums \\"The Who Sell Out\\" (1968), \\"Tommy\\" (1969), \\"Who's Next\\" (1971), and \\"Quadrophenia\\" (1973) to bury in a time capsule with assurance that, when unearthed by archaeologists 2,000 years hence, the vigor, spirit, urges, concerns, and musical vocabulary of the first quarter century of rock 'n roll would be amply represented and potently distilled.<br />  The Who were by no means a seamless ensemble. Musically and temperamentally they were more distinguished by their individuality than by their cohesion. The subtraction of any one of their members, though, would have meant a sundering of the whole, a fact sadly demonstrated in 1978 when rambunctious drummer Keith Moon died shortly after the release of \\"Who Are You?\\", the band's last  hit. Each of the three other band mates ventured solo careers. Roger Daltry struggled to find suitable material for his rugged voice. John Entwhistle harnessed melodic, ostinato-free bass figures with brass sections and his sardonic sense of humor in several albums, but could not sustain commercial viability. Only Pete Townshend possessed sufficient artistry and imagination to craft exciting, affecting songs in his own right.<br />  If there had ever been any doubts, it became clear in later years that The Who had been Pete Townshend's band all along. The tensile strength in Townshend's direct, introspective writing embodied thoughtful vulnerability even as his music summoned thunder. The Who wanted their performances to be seen and felt as much as heard. Their decibel level pressurized eardrums and their stage antics - with the windmill guitar chords, the amplifiers pounded for feedback, and the furious destruction of guitars and drum kits - suggested rage shrugging off restraint.<br />  The band members were notoriously fractious. In their interviews, Daltry and Townshend are candid about their difficulties in working together, as well as their personal weaknesses, creative failures, and affection for intoxicating substances.<br />  \\"Six Quick Ones\\" is designed to be complementary with \\"The Story of The Who.\\" It covers some of the same material, including some of the same interviews and documentary footage. Where the first film presents a chronological history of The Who, the second is organized into six segments (plus bonus material) bringing into focus each of the band's four members, a study of the group's conceptual framework and art school influences, and a recording session that spotlights The Who as constituted in 2003.<br />  All writing about music suffers from being naturally unmusical. Its purpose is typically critical, expository, or promotional. Even if it were cast in lyric poetry with inspired phonemes and complex rhythms, it would still be language, absent melodic pitch, timbre, harmony, and sonic dimension. This review of \\"Amazing Journey\\" can offer only arid sentiment and parched opinion. The DVDs invite the viewer with a thirst for The Who or for the popular music of the '60s and '70s to sip cool draughts straight from the wellspring.es in working together, as well as their personal weaknesses, creative failures, and affection for intoxicating substances.      \\"Six Quick Ones\\" is designed to be complementary with \\"The Story of The Who.\\" It covers some of the same material, including some of the same interviews and documentary footage. Where the first film presents a chronological history of The Who, the second is organized into six segments (plus bonus material) bringing into focus each of the band's four members, a study of the group's conceptual framework and art school influences, and a recording session that spotlights The Who as constituted in 2003.      All writing about music suffers from being naturally unmusical. Its purpose is typically critical, expository, or promotional. Even if it were cast in lyric poetry with inspired phonemes and complex rhythms, it would still be language, absent melodic pitch, timbre, harmony, and sonic dimension. This review of \\"Amazing Journey\\" can offer only arid sentiment and parched opinion. The DVDs invite the viewer with a thirst for The Who or for the popular music of the '60s and '70s to sip cool draughts straight from the wellspring.

0307454541|5.0|Mikael Blomqvist is a financial reporter who has just been found guilty of libel in his investigation of the Wennerstrom Corporation. His career in ruins, his finances in tatters and with a few months to get his life in order before he goes to jail he is a man adrift.  When he is approached by Henrik Vanger to investigate the disappearance of his niece Harriet 40 years earlier, Blomkvist takes on the project, especially because Vanger promises to give him information that will take down Wennerstrom.<br /><br />Lisabeth Sanders is a multi-pierced, multi tattooed young woman with severe anti-social problems. She works for the Milton Security Company, doing freelance investigations and deep backround checks on people. When she is hired to investigate Blomkvist she is slowly drawn into the Vanger story and soon Mikael and Lisabeth's paths will cross, changing both of their lives forever.<br /><br />The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is a crime thriller, but it is not formulaic at all. It touches on a number of topics, including the greed of corporations with no regard for consequences, Nazism, sexual mores and abuse.<br /><br />The story is a little slow moving at first, but when the Vanger investigation takes off it moves at a breakneck pace.  Although Larsson is juggling a number of story lines he is able to weave them all together in an involving and satisfying manner.<br /><br />There are a lot of characters in this book but Lisabeth and her story is the one we end up caring most about. This is a woman who is brilliant yet unlikeable, she does not know how to interact with or trust people.  She is tiny yet she can be brutal, giving off a sense of danger lurking just beneath. As her story unfolds we see the vulnerability hidden away, Lisabeth has been treated very poorly by society; she is betrayed and abused by people, mostly men, time and time again.  She also has a black and white sense of wrong and right, her own moral code; Lisbeth has no problems exacting revenge on those she believes most deserving of it. As she tries to learn the boundaries of her friendship with Mikael, we are rooting for her to find her place in the world, hoping against hope that everything will turn out okay for her.<br /><br />The ending of the book, while satisfying to some extent, is very open ended, making one anxious to pick up the next book in the series.serving of it. B0034G4OU4|3.0|Like anyone who has the slightest interest in seeing this 2010 film, I was seduced by the Travel Channel images in the trailer and the sight of a radiant Julia Roberts in her first full-fledged star vehicle since 2003's [[ASIN:B0001ADAVK Mona Lisa Smile]]. She appears in almost every frame of this 133-minute emotional travelogue, and the introspective story based on Elizabeth Gilbert's 2006 memoir, [[ASIN:0143118420 Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia]], needs someone of Roberts' star wattage to give it a recognizable pulse. The challenge faced by director/writer Ryan Murphy ([[ASIN:B0032JTV6U Glee]]) and his co-screenwriter, former actress Jennifer Salt, is how to make something dramatic out of what is essentially an inward quest toward self-fulfillment without turning the whole venture into a mire of clich&eacute;s that passes for dramatic structure. They don't actually succeed, but somehow Roberts' goodwill and infectious manner, missing for most of the decade, overcome much of this obstacle in her sympathetic portrayal of Gilbert.<br /><br />After a brief preface in Bali where Gilbert interviews a prophetic medicine man who forecasts her love life, the plot begins in earnest with Gilbert's emotional meltdown back in New York six months later. Liz (as the character is called in the movie) divorces her flaky husband Stephen who has upended their marriage with plans to go back to school. She rebounds in a passionate affair with David, a younger actor, but recognizes how she again submerges her own identity in the relationship. In order to halt this recurring pattern and find enlightenment toward her true self, Liz decides to take a trip around the world with three destinations in mind - Italy where she eats, India where she prays, and Bali where she falls in love. Her first stop is Rome, where a young Italian tutor teaches her the art of doing nothing. With the help of her new Swedish best friend, this means accepting the ten extra pounds on her frame due to a steady diet of pasta and pizza. Liz then moves on to an Indian ashram where she receives essential spiritual guidance from a tough-talking Texan named Richard.<br /><br />She finally comes back to Bali to reunite with the medicine man and then accidentally meets Felipe, a recently divorced Brazilian who may or may not turn out to be her soul mate. Because Murphy and Salt appear intent on remaining faithful to the book, they attempt to cover too much for a feature-length film. Secondary characters become trivialized, and situations become rushed and pat. Take, for example, Liz's relationship with a healer named Wayan in Bali. So moved is Liz by Wayan's plight, she emails all her previous travel acquaintances to send money in order to buy Wayan and her young daughter a house. Yet, we get very little sense of any meaningful friendship between the characters. That's because the movie fails to capture the deep emptiness of Liz's soul that would drive her to make this life-altering journey. This is what the author did better in the source book, i.e., show the underbelly of Liz's despair through insightful comments and some pithy prose. As the movie stands, it's left to Roberts to flesh out the character's emotions without sounding like a whining, privileged woman of means. It's no small feat.<br /><br />When not providing the sometimes smug narration, Roberts is luminous but not the film's only standout. Even though his character has to provide the hoariest bromides, Richard Jenkins ([[ASIN:B0015OKWKI The Visitor]]) manages to bring fiery heart and gravitas to the Texan who forces Liz to take a hard look at herself. As Felipe, Javier Bardem ([[ASIN:B001DJ7PR8 Vicky Cristina Barcelona]]) has to play the feminist ideal of the modern man and consequently comes across almost too evolved to be honestly compelling. Less impactful turns are provided by Billy Crudup as Stephen (though his scene at Liz's divorce lawyer's office providesa much-needed edge to the story), James Franco rather morose as David, and Viola Davis ([[ASIN:B001PA0FFO Doubt]]) as wisecracking best friend and editor Delia (similar to the role she played in [[ASIN:B0017ANB08 Nights in Rodanthe]]). Robert Richardson provides the rich cinematography that captures the ripeness of each exotic location down to the luscious pasta dishes in Rome. In fact, aficionados of both the Food Network and the Travel Channel will likely rejoice at the visual pleasures in this film. The rest of us will have to make do with Julia in her prime.ory), James Franco rather morose as David, and Viola Davis ([[ASIN:B001PA0FFO Doubt]]) as wisecracking best friend and editor Delia (similar to the role she played in [[ASIN:B0017ANB08 Nights in Rodanthe]]). Robert Richardson provides the rich cinematography that captures the ripeness of each exotic location down to the luscious pasta dishes in Rome. In fact, aficionados of both the Food Network and the Travel Channel will likely rejoice at the visual pleasures in this film. The rest of us will have to make do with Julia in her prime.

0525951652|4.0|This book (or should I same tome) is a great saga for readers who want a varied cast of characters placed with precision into World War I.  Follett drew sharp class distinctions which fomented the rise of the working class and presented history based on real events.  Through five interconnected Welsh, American, German, Russian and English families, he carries the reader through this historical period with his usual brilliant research.<br /><br />The characters are perfectly placed in their roles:  Billy, the Welsh child who is sent down to the mines at 13 years old, two Russian brothers who, although, separated, are reunited by coincidence, Ethel who is smart and tries to move above her station with disastrous results, the American Dewar who is sensitive to the plight of the peasants and so on.  These somewhat stereotyped characters and the incidents are contrived.  I wanted to read about more atypical characters situated in bizarre incidents. Follett is a great story-teller and the reader should be confident with his accuracy about the events and power plays leading up to WWI.  One must keep in mind, however, that it is an historical novel and many conversations are embellished or created for purpose of the plot<br /><br />Follett certainly provoked a strong dislike for the upper class, particularly the Russians.  I disliked Princess Bea when she was introduced and empathized with the Russian peasants who believed the Tsar loved them as he ordered their hanging. The upper classes are fascinating.  No one can speak until the King (George V) speaks and beating your servants is a good thing. Social justice will prevail ultimately and we are also anxious for a woman's right to vote, but although this is a great page turner (almost 1000 pages!), it is loaded with cliches.  I give Follett an A for history and C+ for characterization.  In hardcover, this book will be very heavy.  It is heavy in pre-publication format; I did not carry it on the train to work!

On the other hand there are plenty of skits and sarcasm to put a spring to your step and a smile on your face.<br /><br />At first the films seems very proud of itself, with not a lot of plot and mostly just a lot of excuses for Julie Andrews to sing.  As the story plays out, the second half gets more into plot, and even there it is a comedy routine.<br /><br />Playing like a silent film, we have a few title cards representing Julie's thoughts as she thinks about her friends and loves.  And there are loooong intermissions of nothing but music, music, music.  It's time for popcorn and a soda, and then back to the movie.<br /><br />Julie plays Millie Dillmount, who has a plan:  get a job, marry the boss and then live happily ever after.  But she runs into a crazy kid named Jimmy and knows she loves him but must find a man who can take care of her.  Jimmy teaches her the Tapioca -- tap tap.<br /><br />Mary Tyler Moore, not yet the apple of Lou Grant's eye in the popular Mary Tyler Moore Show, plays a shy, naive girl who has checked into the Priscilla Hotel for Single Girls, and is targeted as a victim in a white slavery plot!<br /><br />Even this potential bit of darkness is polished off with style and comedy.  But as I said, this film is quite long.  If you're going to rent it, turn up your TV and at the appropriate intermissions fix yourself some cheese and crackers.<br /><br />You have time.<br /><br />Other Favorite Julie Andrews Films:<br /><br />[[ASIN:B00068NVG6 Rodgers & Hammerstein's Cinderella (1957 Television Production)]]<br />[[ASIN:B000AP04OM The Sound of Music (Two-Disc 40th Anniversary Special Edition)]]<br />[[ASIN:B00003CXD9 Victor/Victoria]]<br />[[ASIN:0788812262 Mary Poppins [VHS]]]

B002ZG999U|3.0|Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone) is a man with nothing to lose. Fearless and void of emotion, he is the Leader, the Sage and the Strategist of this tight-knit band of men who live on the fringe. His only attachment is to his pickup truck, his seaplane and his team of loyal modern-day warriors. His is a true cynic who describes what he does as \\"removing those hard to get at stains\\". The team behind him is made up of Lee Christmas (Jason Statham), former SAS and a savant with anything that has a blade; Yin Yang (Jet Li), a master at close-quarter combat; Hale Caesar (Terry Crews), who has known Barney for ten years and is a long-barrel weapons specialist; Toll Road (Randy Couture), a skilled demolitions expert and considered the intellect of the group; and Gunnar Jensen (Dolph Lundgren), a combat veteran and an expert in precision sniping who struggles with his own demons.<br /><br />With the all-star -cast, the expectations are naturally very high, and whether director Sylvester Stallone simply could deliver will remain a subject of debate for a long time. Keeping aside Bruce Willis, Crews or Mickey Rourke (painting guitars and smoking pipe), Jet Li and Dolph Lundgren were expected to have a solo fight scene each.
B002SJIO4A|2.0|This movie has received quite a bit of positive attention, and I must say I'm at a loss to understand.  I've read through the positive reviews here and understand that people like it, but I I'm still not sure why.  I will concede that it is impressively made and that the lead actor does a very good job (although I wouldn't say the same for the rest of the cast).  However, the script is a little weak and filled with questionable character motiviations and plot twists seemingly designed to eke out the maximum amount of gore from the project.  But my main gripe is that when all is done, the film doesn't accomplish anything.    The first 10 minutes of the film sets up a potentially interesting premise.  The following 20 or 30 minutes sets up a plot twist that could have lead to a fascinating follow up.  What happens instead, unfortunately, is a 90 minute shoot-'em-up manhunt that squanders any potential set up by the beginning.  Not only is it disappointing, but it's kind of disgusting to watch.    The violence is both explicit and relentless, and all of it is gratuitous.  The film EASILY could have achieved its aims with only a tenth of the gore.  Pathetic.  And of course it doesn't skim on the grotesque, showing agonizing acts of mayhem and painful biological transition.  If you like movies like \\"Saw\\" or \\"Hostel,\\" you might have a taste for this style of film making, but I avoid such films like the plague.    The way the film chose to portray the alien race was bizarre.  With the exception of one father and his son, it was a race of savages, a bipedal equivalent of ravenous jackals.  (Now that I think of it, the humans in the film weren't portrayed any better.)  As such, it is difficult to know what to make of the situation--are we to pity them because of the oppression they suffer, or are the humans justifiably confining them for their (the humans') own protection?  The film could have served as an analogy to apartheid or anti-immigration sentiment, but without eliciting a shred of empathy for either side, it falls flat in this regard.    So, then, what's with the oft-cited praise that this film is somehow a \\"parable for our times\\"?  A parable?  What's the message, then?  That all living creatures are despicable?  That it's only a matter of time before rival sects destroy one another?  That we have nothing better to do with 90 minutes of our time than to watch exploding heads and acts of mayhem?  Indeed, I implore anyone who applauds this movie to tell what they learned from it.  (There very well could be something that I'm not getting--I really want to know!)    As Eckhart Tolle would say, this is a move made by pain-bodies for pain-bodies.  I'm still a weasel and a wretch, but there must be hope for me, because this movie turned my stomach.    Still, fair is fair.  Two stars for the effort put into it, the lead actor, and the special effects.  Also, this movie was strongly recommended to me by someone whose opinion I respect, so your reaction to this horrifically ugly movie may vary from mine (see what I did there?).
0307266303|4.0|The Tarahumara tribe, also known as \\"The Running People\\", live deep in the rugged Copper Canyon Mountains of Mexico, isolated from electricity, urbanization, even the embrace of paved roads.<br /><br />Physical isolation and an enduring spirit have for generations allowed the Tarahumara to successfully and obstinately cling to their ancient traditions and way of life in the face of an ever-changing world.<br /><br />The Tarahumara's drive to preserve their culture and traditions- as well as their ability to run freakishly long distances with apparent ease- fill Christopher McDougall with an intense curiosity, and give him the subject for a lasting, endearing tale about possibility.<br /><br />In [[ASIN:0307266303 Born to Run: A Hidden Tribe, Superathletes, and the Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen]], McDougall brings alive a host of wildly entertaining characters: the elusive, quixotic Caballo (or \\"White Horse\\"), the empathic and super-talented ultra marathoning great, Scott Jurek, the wild, hard-drinking duo of young running talents, Jenn and Billy, and others, as these characters decide to go along with the seemingly half-baked plan of Caballo's- to stage the \\"Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen\\". A race that would pit the Running People up against a group of super running talents from the United States.<br /><br />McDougall tells this story of the Tarahumara, their band of admirers, and the great race between these two forces of talent with a deft ear for pacing. One scene cuts to the next, the narrative bouncing along, in stride and brimming over with life and an addictive momentum.<br /><br />Also helping the momentum of the narrative, are the factoids and knowledge about health and running McDougall inserts masterly into the story: how engineering advancements in running shoes have helped to increase injury, the restorative benefits of chia, piniole, geranium and other dietary particularities of the Tarahumara, theories on the origin of the human species, etc.<br /><br />The craftsmanship, information, and heart-pumping narrative all blend together to tell an inspiring tale of love and human possibility. This book will inspire you: to run farther, eat healthier, love harder, and dream more about what the human body and mind can achieve.<br /><br />In ultra-running, McDougall finds an apt metaphor for the endurance of the human spirit, the tendency of love and community to conquer, against all odds, the stultifying push of time.ation, and heart-pumping narrative all blend together to tell an inspiring tale of love and human possibility. This book will inspire you: to run farther, eat healthier, love harder, and dream more about what the human body and mind can achieve. 1601251505|5.0|I aim this review at people wondering whether to go with D&D 4th Edition (4e) or Pathfinder, clicking back and forth between the two on Amazon like I was when deciding which system to run with my friends, all of whom are new to tabletop RPGs. However, there is a caveat to this review, in that I am brand-new to tabletop RPGs and have not yet played 4e. Still, I obsessed(!) about this, read the rulebooks for both editions, and simulated both on my own to the extent that I can. I welcome comments that can flesh out or critique what I am about to say.<br /><br />Twenty-two years ago, when I was ten or so, I obsessively read over the manuals and some early adventures for the Basic Dungeons & Dragons ruleset. However, I never found a group that shared my passion - video games and the Nintendo Entertainment System were occupying most people my age. I was no exception and soon moved on to video and computer games to get the closest I could get to the \\"genuine\\" role-playing experience.<br /><br />Fast forward to the present day, and I am beginning tabletop RPGs for the first time, attracted by the freedom for imagination and the collective experience that they bring.<br /><br />I chose Pathfinder because I was attracted to the attention to \\"realism\\" (to the extent one can say realism exists in an imagined fantasy world - the word I've seen used is \\"verisimilitude\\"). I was turned off by the idea in D&D 4th Edition of critically-wounded characters taking a night's sleep and waking up without a scratch, and the mystical \\"healing surges\\" (which 4e doesn't even attempt to give an in-game justification for) that characters can employ during and between encounters. The disdaining comparisons between 4e and World of Warcraft and other video games, while often over-simplified and overused, does have merit in that 4e is focused on providing a specific gaming experience that, while attractive and highly-enjoyable to those who prefer more of the action, pacing and feel of video games, just wasn't my cup of tea.<br /><br />On the other hand, Pathfinder's (and previously D&D 3.5 Edition's) commitment to \\"realism\\" also added another order of complexity to the gaming system. This was the main reason why I hesitated in running Pathfinder. There was a huge number of options for each character class; the magic spells are not standardized and require the GM to study the spells (in addition to the characters' various powers), with all their mini rulesets, beforehand; some of the \\"stat blocks\\" for the monsters involve some extensive preparation... In particular, I was concerned that the players would be turned off or intimidated by the rules, since none of them I would describe yet as \\"hardcore\\" RPG players.<br /><br />But now, after having run my first session, I can now say the following. I can assure any person who is a committed GM (like myself), that the complexity is not a problem for players. The players only need to know some basics to play in a Pathfinder game - all the rules about flanking, limits on casting spells while adjacent to an opponent, etc., can all be introduced piece-by-piece as they become relevant throughout a given game. Every player is free to spend extra time between gaming sessions to get a copy of the Core Rulebook for themselves if they want to fully customize their character, know what other actions they can take, etc. Also, to the extent I have compared Pathfinder with the system it is based on (D&D 3.5 Edition), Pathfinder has made an effort to avoid unnecessary complexity and has streamlined certain rules. On my own end as the GM, I think I'll get to know the ins and outs of the rules and various spells in due time.<br /><br />Mind you, I had never even PLAYED a tabletop RPG before, and I am saying that the first session I RAN went (relatively!) smoothly. (I ran Crypt of the Everflame, which is a good introductory module for players and GMs.) However, this is not to suggest that learning how to run Pathfinder is easy - it takes quite a bit of preparation. However, if you are enthusiastic about the project to begin with, the process of preparing and looking forward to the experience you can give players should be a source of joy in itself. Also, many of the rules are derived from a \\"real-world logic,\\" and don't pose the challenge of memorizing a set of \\"gamey\\", suspended-in-midair rules from 4th Edition, such as enabling clerics to heal nearby allies by allowing them to \\"spend\\" one of THEIR OWN healing surges for free (unless of course those other players ran out of healing surges for that day), or that magic items can only be sold for 20% their purchasing value, or that wizards can unlock doors only by spending money and waiting 10 minutes... instances in the rules that seem to challenge my own internal effort to \\"keep the world together\\" for my players. (I want to avoid those moments of telling players \\"you can't do that\\" when there is little for me to say to back it up.)<br /><br />On a similar note, the \\"complexity\\" of the character classes was itself a big draw to the players. The sheer number of options for each character class got people's imaginations going. They especially enjoyed the \\"flavor\\" paragraphs that gave a broad, romantic overview of each character class and provided a context for each class's powers. And, of course, the variation among character classes is much wider than in D&D 4th Edition - not only does a Wizard indeed \\"feel\\" much different from a Fighter, but also a Fighter with her background of training in fighting skills (feats) \\"feels\\" different from another front-line bruiser, the Barbarian. And the amount of options WITHIN each character class, especially with the Advanced Player's Guide that has just been released, is thrilling.<br /><br />I have read people who prefer 4th Edition argue that the relatively smaller number of rules in 4e allows \\"more room\\" for roleplaying and imagination, but I honestly don't understand that argument. Any roleplaying system must have a set of rules, a set of confines that provide restrictions, IN ORDER for imagination to flourish. In order to \\"feel\\" like a parallel to our real-world experience, which DOES operate within restrictions, a fantasy world must have its own internally-consistent set of \\"laws.\\" Is this a world I can see myself living in? Then, it's the bending and breaking of the rules (by a wizard using magic, by the scrappy street urchins rising to become heroes of their realm, etc.) that makes fantasy into fantasy. Otherwise, what you have is a blank slate, and if you're a novice GM (like I am), it is a blank slate that will be drawn upon by a novice.<br /><br />The danger of \\"too many\\" rules, is having rules that provide an OBSTACLE to roleplaying. For example, one doesn't want to impose a mythology or an essentialism upon the setting or characters that provide restrictions to players' imagination (4th Edition's description that dwarves \\"revere Moradin\\" and \\"play a dwarf if you want to be tough\\" comes to mind). Of course, no one is bound to stick to everything in a given rule system, and the example I just mentioned can be dismissed and other problems in 4e can be \\"house ruled away.\\" I would just rather not have to do that work as a GM. And some \\"rules\\" and \\"complexity\\" can provide FUEL to imagination: a perusal of Pathfinder's character class descriptions, or spell descriptions, or wacky cursed items, give me inspiration for hundreds of possible traps and storylines.<br /><br />(As an aside, I am not sure I like Pathfinder's \\"skills\\" system - I want to roleplay a negotiation with a player and not involve a roll of the dice. At the same time, I see how that mechanic rewards a player who has chosen to be, say, a rogue who is highly skilled in this area. I'm not quite sure how to deal with that... but the way 4e deals with this is even more mechanical and worse.)<br /><br />So having \\"fewer\\" rules is not automatically better. And to be honest, that is a cop-out: it's the game designers whose job it is to supply the rules, and it's the players who supply the imagination. The question is whether the rules system, which is the responsibility of the game designers, provide starting-off points and inspiration to the imagination.<br /><br />Also, because Pathfinder is easily backward-compatible to the entire D&D 3.5 Edition's line of adventure modules (from WOTC and third-party publishers), there are many excellent adventures that are ready for me to use than there currently are for 4e.<br /><br />My last comment is about Pathfinder's new Advanced Player's Guide, which demonstrates a big reason why I chose Pathfinder over 4e: the business model. D&D's publisher, Wizards of the Coast, has created a product line that requires spending more and more money to stay up-to-date. They have just released \\"Player's Handbook 3,\\" and one who buys the first Player's Handbook simply doesn't have the current game and must buy more recent offerings: they purposely excluded the popular Druid and Monk classes so they could publish them in the 2nd and 3rd Player's Handbooks, respectively. (WOTC, by the way, is credited by some older fans of Magic The Gathering of having \\"broken\\" the game balance, because every new set of cards would include powers that \\"broke\\" strategic considerations from previous cardsets and required every player to buy new cardsets whenever they came out.) In contrast, Pathfinder's Advanced Player's Guide has hundreds of pages of archetypes for the core classes, alternative base classes, alternative racial traits, and more... all of which are optional. And, there is a genuine effort not to break the game balance and force customers to buy this book. (For example, all the optional new class powers are in exchange for class powers from the Core Rulebook.) Sure, they're still double-dipping and making me want to buy their shiny new book, but it's a very well-done book and one that I don't absolutely HAVE to buy.<br /><br />I simply don't get the feeling that Paizo, the publishers of Pathfinder, have sold their souls to Asmodeus. Their origins as being the writers and publishers for Dungeon magazine before they were booted by WOTC mean that, for now, they are relatively gamer-focused as a company. The quality of their Pathfinder Adventure Paths (6-part adventure modules) have given them a well-deserved reputation as being \\"by gamers, for gamers.\\" Oh, and sweeping the Ennies (the \\"Oscars\\" of the RPG world) this month and winning Gold for Best Game (Pathfinder RPG) and Best Publisher ain't bad, either. (Congratulations, Paizo: they're well-deserved.)<br /><br />So that's my two cents if you ask me: go with Pathfinder, and then go to the Paizo/Pathfinder messageboards, where you'll find a very supportive and enthusiastic gaming community you can join. :)rictions, IN ORDER for imagination to flourish. In order to \\"feel\\" like a parallel to our real-world experience, which DOES operate within restrictions, a fantasy world must have its own internally-consistent set of \\"laws.\\" Is this a world I can see myself living in? Then, it's the bending and breaking of the rules (by a wizard using magic, by the scrappy street urchins rising to become heroes of their realm, etc.) that makes fantasy into fantasy. Otherwise, what you have is a blank slate, and if you're a novice GM (like I am), it is a blank slate that will be drawn upon by a novice.     The danger of \\"too many\\" rules, is having rules that provide an OBSTACLE to roleplaying. For example, one doesn't want to impose a mythology or an essentialism upon the setting or characters that provide restrictions to players' imagination (4th Edition's description that dwarves \\"revere Moradin\\" and \\"play a dwarf if you want to be tough\\" comes to mind). Of course, no one is bound to stick to everything in a given rule system, and the example I just mentioned can be dismissed and other problems in 4e can be \\"house ruled away.\\" I would just rather not have to do that work as a GM. And some \\"rules\\" and \\"complexity\\" can provide FUEL to imagination: a perusal of Pathfinder's character class descriptions, or spell descriptions, or wacky cursed items, give me inspiration for hundreds of possible traps and storylines.     (As an aside, I am not sure I like Pathfinder's \\"skills\\" system - I want to roleplay a negotiation with a player and not involve a roll of the dice. At the same time, I see how that mechanic rewards a player who has chosen to be, say, a rogue who is highly skilled in this area. I'm not quite sure how to deal with that... but the way 4e deals with this is even more mechanical and worse.)    So having \\"fewer\\" rules is not automatically better. And to be honest, that is a cop-out: it's the game designers whose job it is to supply the rules, and it's the players who supply the imagination. The question is whether the rules system, which is the responsibility of the game designers, provide starting-off points and inspiration to the imagination.     Also, because Pathfinder is easily backward-compatible to the entire D&D 3.5 Edition's line of adventure modules (from WOTC and third-party publishers), there are many excellent adventures that are ready for me to use than there currently are for 4e.    My last comment is about Pathfinder's new Advanced Player's Guide, which demonstrates a big reason why I chose Pathfinder over 4e: the business model. D&D's publisher, Wizards of the Coast, has created a product line that requires spending more and more money to stay up-to-date. They have just released \\"Player's Handbook 3,\\" and one who buys the first Player's Handbook simply doesn't have the current game and must buy more recent offerings: they purposely excluded the popular Druid and Monk classes so they could publish them in the 2nd and 3rd Player's Handbooks, respectively. (WOTC, by the way, is credited by some older fans of Magic The Gathering of having \\"broken\\" the game balance, because every new set of cards would include powers that \\"broke\\" strategic considerations from previous cardsets and required every player to buy new cardsets whenever they came out.) In contrast, Pathfinder's Advanced Player's Guide has hundreds of pages of archetypes for the core classes, alternative base classes, alternative racial traits, and more... all of which are optional. And, there is a genuine effort not to break the game balance and force customers to buy this book. (For example, all the optional new class powers are in exchange for class powers from the Core Rulebook.) Sure, they're still double-dipping and making me want to buy their shiny new book, but it's a very well-done book and one that I don't absolutely HAVE to buy.    I simply don't get the feeling that Paizo, the publishers of Pathfinder, have sold their souls to Asmodeus. Their origins asbeing the writers and publishers for Dungeon magazine before they were booted by WOTC mean that, for now, they are relatively gamer-focused as a company. The quality of their Pathfinder Adventure Paths (6-part adventure modules) have given them a well-deserved reputation as being \\"by gamers, for gamers.\\" Oh, and sweeping the Ennies (the \\"Oscars\\" of the RPG world) this month and winning Gold for Best Game (Pathfinder RPG) and Best Publisher ain't bad, either. (Congratulations, Paizo: they're well-deserved.)    So that's my two cents if you ask me: go with Pathfinder, and then go to the Paizo/Pathfinder messageboards, where you'll find a very supportive and enthusiastic gaming community you can join. :)

B003A4IFGY|5.0|Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers continue to amaze. Mojo is their first studio work in years,and is well worth the wait. Petty and the band return to their southern-rock roots, heavily influenced by traditional blues motifs, in a terrific blast from the past made possible only by decades of playing together.<br /><br />I bought the CD before seeing Tom during this summer's tour, wanting to be familiar with the \\"new stuff\\" before I saw him in person. As it turns out, he's giving away free downloads of the CD with the price of the concert ticket (even so, I'm glad I bought the CD).<br /><br />For those of us of an earlier generation - who can recall the British invasion, and understand that it was groups from England which served to introduce white American teenagers to American blues - this CD is a reminder of how American bands took up the task of reinterpreting our own musical heritage, and built upon it.<br /><br />From a production standpoint, the CD is refreshingly \\"under produced\\" and gives the impression of a group of guys standing around some microphones and doing the songs in a single take. It has immediacy and life that are hard to find in other contemporary music.<br /><br />Great CD.

B003DO13NS|5.0|Mike Oldfield has been called pretentious, egotistical, and similar uncomplimentary synonyms. I find his efforts unique, transformational, and highly creative.  His work, at its best, is a 20-21st century successor to the classical tradition, especially his long-form works.<br /><br />Hergest Ridge is a terrific example of his extraordinary compositional range, melding together elements of tone-poetry with rock, jazz, and orchestral influences. This is not as iconoclastic as Tubular Bells, and is more similar to Ommadawn in that it demands close attention to appreciate its much more subtle aspects.<br /><br />This particular work might be labled as \\"New Age\\" by some, but don't confuse Hergest Ridge with the background tunes at your local spa. Don't light candles and meditate to this music. Listen closely and appreciate real artistry at work - it's well worth the effort.

B003H3IOLE|5.0|A friend recommended this novel since I enjoy historical fiction.  A Tree Grows in Brooklyn follows the path of a turn of the 20th century family in Brooklyn. Although Ms. Smith wrote the book in the 1940s, its message is timeless. The reader watches as the central character, Francie, grows up determined to have a better life for herself.  Francie is 2nd generation American who comes from a working class neighborhood of Brooklyn.      Francie adores her Irish father who does not have steady work and often comes home drunk.  Her father loves Francie dearly and encourages her to dream and to become a writer.  He even supports her efforts to go to a better school despite the distance the school is from their home.    Francie's mother, Katie, works hard and long as a housekeeper and keeps the family together.  Katie recognizes the value of education and reads to her children from the Bible and Shakespere nightly.  She also encourages their imagination.  When the family moved into a house with a piano, Katie had the children sit with her during lessons so that they all could learn to play since the family could hardly afford lessons for one.      Francie is very close to her brother, one year her junior, who is also pushed to achieve more than what the parents have been able to do.    While money is always tight, the family always has a roof over their heads and usually they have food.  Francie's maternal grandmother and aunts add to the moral fabric and are there to support the family when needed.      There is conflict between having the children work so that the family can survive vs. allowing them to focus on education.  Francie and her brother are able to do both, but the logic that Katie uses when forced to choose was not intuitive, but the right choice.      What I loved about the book is that it showed how the children grew up with very little material things.  Another message is to look at everything around you with the attitude as if it was the first or last time that you have seen such things.  Recognize beauty of which it beholds and you will live a much for fulfilled and hopeful life.   Sure, the children had conflicts with their parents, but in the end, they recognized how important their relationship was with each other and that having money didn't equate to having happiness.  It is a wonderful, timeless, coming of age story that should be required reading for today's youth.

It's tough to get out of the rut he's in, but he does eventually, and learns hope through his daughter.  It was a touching moment for me to read it, even as his whole world is crumbling.    I felt like as Dex and Em's relationship evolved over the twenty years, it was showing a huge part of growing up and maturity occurring on the part of both.  And sometimes that has to happen.  We don't realize how things have changed between when you are forty and when you are twenty, and David Nicholls shows how people change for the better, and that the memories of a love are both bitter and sweet.
