B003ITZBW2|4.0|Fitting three major villains and the mysterious namesake character into a 75 minute film is an admirably but perhaps overly ambitious project. Spiderman 3 couldn't pull off a three villain story with two hours.   Luckily the creators - mostly Judd Winnick, adapting his own comic - know what they're doing, and bring together multiple strands of Batman history that adds to, rather than distracts from, the central story.    As a viewer with only a dim knowledge of the Batman comics history, I went into this without any strong opinion about Jason Todd, apparently a favorite target of fanboys, whose death at the hands of the Joker opens the film. Five years later, a vigilante known as the Red Hood makes his presence known in Gotham's underworld, mainly by killing and manipulating its members. The highest-profile of these members is Black Mask, who spends a lot of money trying to get rid of the new presence and who eventually asks for the Joker's help (spoiler: this ends up being a bad move). Batman's attention is necessarily demanded, and he approaches the Red Hood pretty much the same way he would approach any villain. Even with the aid of Nightwing, though, Batman is unable to apprehend him, a failure made eerier by the fact that the Red Hood seems to know an awful lot about the Dark Knight.     Viewers expecting a typical DC Animated Universe outing might be shocked at the level of violence here. The grisly opening scene, while not showing anything more than a bit of blood, is still quite striking relative to the level of violence seen in other Batman animated releases. And this is only the start - lots of gun deaths and (offscreen) immolation and decapitation occur as well. It certainly earns its PG-13 rating, unlike, say, the uncut version of \\"Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker.\\"    This heightened violence is beneficial to the film for a number of reasons. In terms of character, it allows for a more psychopathic, less clowny version of the Joker. Fans will doubtless be comparing this version to the standard, Mark Hammill voiced DCAU incarnation, to which there is some resemblance. There are some sick laughs to be had in John DiMaggio's wry, sneering delivery, but this Joker is far more interested in death and destruction than theatrics. In terms of story and theme, it allows for the Red Hood character to be a vicious killer while undeniably undercutting the influence of Gotham's scum, bringing Batman's absolute injunction against killing into question on pragmatic and even ethical grounds.    The film's technical aspects are first-rate. Voice acting is solid all around. Bruce Greenwood's Batman is pretty similar to Kevin Conroy, a good thing for most DCAU fans. Jensen Ackles does superbly as the Red Hood, giving the character a range of emotion from callous indifference to impassioned humanity. As mentioned, DiMaggio's Joker is convincingly psychopathic. We could have used more Neil Patrick Harris as Nightwing, who provides the bulk of the comic relief. Jason Isaacs delivers his few lines as Ra's Al Ghul with a silky elegance. The fight scenes, of which there are a lot, are inventive and visceral. Save for a couple of confusing gadgets, the action is coherent.    The climax is the source of the film's only problems. A long dialogue about the conflicting morality behind the Red Hood and Batman's actions was inevitable, but it's handled clumsily. Also, the phrase \\"Good Lord\\" comes up a bit too much, and the two vigilantes reminded me of a couple of born-again Christians trying to hold back swears. This is quite a minor complaint, but it just seemed whitewashed.    Overall this is a very dark and sophisticated film, and a fine addition to the DCAU.
030745455X|5.0|I cannot for the life of me understand how there are so many people who did not like this book.  Yes, it is descriptive.  Yes, it is long.  And yes, it was impossible to put down.  I am almost always a reader of nonfiction but I picked up the first book in this series (Dragon Tattoo)based off of the massive hype and I immediately went out and bought the second when I was finished and then the third and so on.<br /><br />Lisbeth Slander is a fantastically complex creation and an utterly engrossing heroine for whom to root for.  It is absolutely worth the time to read through and see all the plot lines and mysteries come together.  How sad that the author passed away and there will be no more Lisbeth Salander.
B002VECLVO|3.0|While the cinematography of A Single Man was meant to dazzle, it gave the movie an overall look of a fashion shoot shoved into Architectural Digest.  The insistently imposing visuals took away from the emotional impact of the story.  In the novel, both George and Charlotte's houses were seedy, run-down, and cramped as are they.  In the movie, George's house was a glassy designer affair with high-end appliances and Charley's was a ridiculously overblown arboretum.  George driving a Mercedes?  He was a prof in a second-rate state college, for god's sake.  Nowhere in the novel was the character of Kenny Potter a girly-faced angel; he was a beaky-nosed redhead whose intellect made him initially attractive to George.  And there was no hustler named Carlos who walked poutily out of a Calvin Klein ad.     The impending suicide by firearm was an obvious and unnecessary structural contrivance.  George's prissy attempts at auditioning various locations in his perfectly appointed house for his finale so not to be messy was a hoot rather than pathetic.  Adding this element went against the spirit of Isherwood's novel, which is a day in the disappointed life of an aging man in profound grief who goes about his quotidian activities with occasional hopeful flashes of recovery--and dies.  Isherwood understood the absurdity of the human condition.  Tom Ford drowned the understated emotional power of the novel with his showing off.  I can't believe that Isherwood's longtime partner, Don Bachardy, who was credited as a creative consultant in this movie, agreed to this revision of the novel.    I waited patiently to see this movie until I finished reading the novel because I didn't want Isherwood's words superimposed by someone else's images, but I see now that it wouldn't have mattered because Tom Ford's movie isn't Christopher Isherwood's novel.  Colin Firth is, of course, amazing as George Falconer; but for a truly moving experience of A Single Man, I suggest a reading of Isherwood's novel instead of this cinematic gay chic.
0061478784|4.0|I had originally seen the movie by Hayao Miyazaki and hadn't even realized that there was a book.  I stumbled across it quite by accident and of course had to read it.  I have to say, I was pretty pleased with it.  Even with my preconceived notions from the movie, I still enjoyed the plot and all the characters in the book.<br /><br />Sophie is the oldest of three girls, and in her world, that means she's due to live an uneventful unlucky life.  When a tough break with a witch leaves her looking like an old woman, she leaves the hat shop where she works and wanders, eventually coming upon Howl's Moving Castle.  While she's heard horrible things about Howl and young women, she figures since she is old now she should be safe.<br /><br />While staying with Howl she learns some of his secrets and makes friends with Calcifer, a fire demon who is bound to Howl and runs the castle.  Along with Michael, his apprentice, Howl has turned this castle into quite the wondrous place. Sophie agrees to help Calcifer in return for his help and becomes Howl's cleaning lady. But will Sophie be able to get back to normal and help Howl with his own problems?  There is an evil witch after him and the King wants his help in finding his brother; he may not have the time to return Sophie to normal.<br /><br />The characters in this novel are pretty delightful.  I especially love Calcifer.  Even though he may just be fire, he's got quite the personality.  Sophie and Howl have interesting interactions and its easy to see that despite their annoyances, they like bantering with each other.  Even the side characters show some interesting traits; after all, this is a world that accepts magic.<br /><br />The writing, since this is technically a kid's book is on the side of easier to understand. There's not a lot of hard language or concepts in the book.  I will say that towards the end of the book the writing gets rushed and hard to follow.  I had really enjoyed the book up until that part but I found myself reading in patches near the end just so I could try to make sense of what was going on.  I think if Jones had just slowed down and detailed a bit more it would have vastly improved it.  Despite the confusion at the end, I'm sure this would make a great book to read to a child.<br /><br />Such a wondrous imaginative book though.  I did enjoy it for the most part.  I know Jones has some other novels out that have been made into movies and I'll probably look into reading them since I enjoyed this one.<br /><br />Howl's Moving Castle<br />Copyright 1986<br />212 pagesar the end just so I could try to make sense of what was going on. B003JTHESA|5.0|\\"The Final Frontier\\" is the best Iron Maiden album since 1988's \\"Seventh Son of a Seventh Son\\".  (It is slightly better than 2000's \\"Brave New World\\").  I can't imagine how anyone who considers themselves an Iron Maiden fan would not love this album.  What makes these songs especially good are the subtleties, stuff that the casual listener might not recognize or appreciate.  \\"The Final Frontier\\" is as rewarding as it is complex.  If it doesn't impress you the first time you hear it, listen again, and pay attention.
B003JTHESA|2.0|2006's A Matter of Life and Death was a complex, heavy record, which took certainly more than one sitting to fully digest and appreciate.  The album boasted several standout tracks - notably, The Reincarnation of Benjamin Breeg and Lord of Light, both of which were on the second batch of songs - but the middle portion of the record seemed to run together, a collection of songs that Steve Harris & Co. seemed to over-compose, extending tracks to 8 minutes where a 4  minute song would have been just as well.  But because so many of these songs had memorable hooks, great melodies, mind-boggling guitar solos and, most of all, heart, they were easy to look past.    This habit was a minor annoyance on AMOLAD, but became a full-blown vice on The Final Frontier, Maiden's first album of new material in four years.  There's no good way to say it: This album stinks.       The band sounds thin, they sound tired, and worst of all, they sound like they're out of ideas.  It is mind-boggling that the songwriting partnerships that have given us latter-day anthems like The Wicker Man, Brave New World, Paschendale and The Legacy have suddenly forgotten how to write good material.  The Final Frontier sounds nothing more than a bunch of the worst ideas from the last three albums - turds that Harris & Co. picked up off the trash heap and tried to polish.  With the exception of Mother of Mercy, Coming Home and perhaps the lead single, El Dorado, none of these songs stand up to even the weakest links on the previous three records (Age of Innocence, Gates of Tomorrow, Different World), but rather hearken back to the truly nauseating Blaze Bayley era of 1994-1998.  The Final Frontier doesn't sound a collection of new, progressive material at all - and what makes this so disheartening is that the band really thinks they've struck gold and made one of the best records of their careers.    There is very little to like on this record.  After Coming Home closes out, listeners are pummeled into boredom by track after track after track of the same old tired thing - a soft, melancholy intro, a staccato guitar riff by one Murray, Smith or Gers, a verse and chorus combination that sounds disjointed, lazy and bereft of melody, the complete lack of anything resembling a groove (does anyone remember how great Rainmaker was?), and the band painstakingly extending nearly every song three minutes longer than it needs to be.  Most disappointing is the album-closing \\"epic\\" When the Wild Wind Blows, which despite its 11-minute running time, never really gets going and seems to have been extended to 11 minutes just because Steve Harris felt like it.  I recently read an interview with Kevin Shirley where he said that, initially, the song was actually just a bunch of separate pieces of music that Harris had written, and the final product was those parts simply stitched together.  It sounds like it.  The lyrics are childish and the melody is weak.  Instead of being pensive and deep, this song sounds like a bad cliche.   After we've been treated to so many fantastic album-closers over the years -- Rime of the Ancient Mariner, Alexander the Great, Journeyman, The Legacy -- THIS is what we're left with?  The emperor has no clothes.    I love the old stuff, sure, but I also love the new stuff.  Brave New World and Dance of Death stand next to Powerslave and Seventh Son of a Seventh Son as the band's best work.  But the difference I see between mid-80s Maiden and the Maiden of 2010 is that, back in the day, the band had a sense of pace, of momentum.  On Powerslave, the band included several epics (among them the 13-minute opus Rime of the Ancient Mariner), sure, but it began the album with the four-minute Aces High, which is blistering from beginning to end.  In fact, examining the band's entire catalog, Maiden's most memorable songs don't fit a particular category.  While epics like Rime of the Ancient Mariner, Hallowed Be Thy Name and Phantom of the Opera are no doubt highlights, so too are the much shorter Wrathchild, Aces High and The Trooper.  Even where Maiden tried to be epic back in the day, they included short songs where short songs were needed - for instance, Only the Good Die Young, the album closer from Seventh Son, which clocks in at under four minutes.  And just as notably, the shorter songs didn't have to begin and end with some sort of pseudo-melancholy arpeggiated intro. Heck, even Futureal manages to stay fast throughout.    It's almost as if Harris & Co. are trying to prove a point that they're not out to write a hit single, and daring the Billboard charts to place them number one despite an album that is as far away from the mainstream as possible.  But this approach is incredibly disappointing.  As far as I can tell, after 15 albums, Iron Maiden has finally run its course.  Whether the problem is producer Kevin Shirley, the band's complacency (I have to say, doesn't it bother anyone that they play virtually the same setlist every single night on tour?) or simply the fact that Maiden is out of ideas, The Final Frontier is one of the single biggest disappointments in recent rock history.  The fact that I've read so many gushing reviews sickens me.  Maybe I bought a counterfeit copy of the album, and the real new record is floating out there somewhere, but I seriously doubt it.  This just isn't good music, as \\"epic\\" as Maiden tries so hard to sound.
B0007PLLQ0|5.0|Love this movie. This is were I fell in love with Tom Cruise. It's a Love, Drama, Action, Adventure, Horror and Fantasy movie all in one. Get it you will love it.    MonieLove
B003JTHESA|4.0|Iron Maiden's The Final Frontier is out today. Honestly first listen I was underwhelmed. By about the third listen I began to love this album overall. There is much speculation that this could be their last album. Obviously the title could be a sign. These guys are pushing 50s and 60s I believe. Which leads me to a couple of observations on the new album.    The pace of their albums continues to slow down. Dance of Death was a true return to form from the 80s imo. I was a little disappointed with A Matter of Life and Death (which I grew to love) as the album did not carry on the blistering paced momentum that Maiden gained with Dance. In every respect I'd say Final Frontier continues the trend of slowing down. This is a more mellow, introspective, even spiritual Iron Maiden. The pace of the album is almost consistent through the entire album. For the most part slow melodic introductions building to mid-tempo, melodic choruses.    Is this bad? In my opinion not at all. Maiden is just different. Sold out? Not even close. Lyrically Final Frontier is fantastic. Again revisiting the theme of war as MoLaD did. There is a definite environmental theme running through this album, specifically on Isle of Avalon (one of my favorite tracks). Most of all, this album is somewhat 'We're all doomed' heavy. There is a sadness and almost surrender to what is coming, what we have brought upon ourselves in the songwriting. 'A Wild Wind in the Willows' closes the album and is to say the least not an uplifting song.    Is this album an end of a 30+ year career? I hope not. After a few listens the moments of brilliance start to come through. Lyrically and theme-wise this album is timely with all that's going on in the world. As a guitar player, there are some 'Wow' moments. Some 'jazz fusion what the hell is that doing on a Maiden album' moments that are really cool. I really like the metal 'Portal' deluxe packaging.    I have a feeling many won't like this album. It is different, but atit's core this is still a Maiden album through and through. Experimental Maiden is better than no Maiden at all.    Up THE IRONS!    Standouts for me:    Mother of Mercy  Isle of Avalon  The Talisman  The Man Who Would Be King  Where the Wild Wind Blows

0452286751|5.0|Wow.  This book was such a treat to read on so many levels!  Don't be intimidated by the length - this book is incredibly readable, and you can read just a few pages at a time and enjoy what you are reading.  However I guarantee by the end you will be up all night to see how it unfolds.  I really was not sure up until the very end.  This book is more than just a story of characters, it is a story of society, of power, and an assessment of what makes man tick.  You can read it at any level you want.  The book has helped me put my finger on many things I have thought about myself and others - it has expressed why I might like or dislike a person, and it explains why different personalities act as they do.  Although the author is strong in her convictions, she allows alot of room for interpretation.  How I interpret scenes may not be how others interpret the same scenes- thus it is a wonderful book for discussion.  This is one of the few books where the character development is sufficient that i actually bothered to \\"question motives\\" of fictional characters - something I usually am uninspired to do.  A word of caution, many of the characters are portrayed in absolutist terms, something which normally does not appeal to me.  However in this book, it really helped to clarify my thinking on the matters which the author is presenting.  In a nutshell, it was more than just brilliant, it was truly memorable.

When mayhem occurs with the witness taking a blood bath in the hotel 5 minutes away, it seems fair to conclude Bullitt thought he was hired as a babysitter.<br />Again, Bullitt doesn't talk very much but his eyes, his mouth, his face convey emotions of a confident man, an intelligent man, with a mind of intrigue. He carries out his plan, not for self glory, or to banish the bad guys, but to expose the corruption because he knows he is good at what he does.<br />McQueen opted for real doctors and real nurses to portray hospital scenes (evidence #2).
